questions.text: In cases of suspected ectopic pregnancy, which hormone is typically measured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Beta hCG

Explanation: Human chorionic gonadotropin (Beta hCG) is the primary hormone measured in suspected ectopic pregnancy.

Key Features:

  • Normal pregnancy: Beta hCG doubles every 48-72 hours
  • Ectopic pregnancy: Slower increase in Beta hCG levels
  • Important diagnostic indicator

Estrogen (Option A): While estrogen levels do increase during pregnancy, they are not specific enough to diagnose ectopic pregnancy. Estrogen measurements cannot determine the location of a pregnancy or distinguish between normal and ectopic implantation.

Progesterone (Option B): Although progesterone levels can indicate pregnancy viability, they cannot differentiate between ectopic and intrauterine pregnancies. Low progesterone suggests a non-viable pregnancy but doesn't confirm its location.

LH (Option D): Luteinizing hormone is only relevant for ovulation and menstrual cycle regulation. It has no role in pregnancy diagnosis or location determination, making it unsuitable for ectopic pregnancy detection.

questions.text: What is the most effective approach to managing mild nausea and vomiting in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Eat small, frequent meals

Explanation: For mild nausea and vomiting during pregnancy, dietary modifications are highly recommended. Eating small, frequent meals can help manage symptoms by preventing the stomach from becoming too empty, which can trigger nausea.

  • Small, frequent meals help maintain stable blood sugar levels
  • Consuming dry biscuits or crackers in the morning on an empty stomach is effective
  • This approach is safe and doesn't require medication
  • It addresses the underlying cause of nausea by preventing an empty stomach

Use domperidone (Option B): Domperidone is a medication used to treat nausea and vomiting but is generally not the first-line treatment for pregnancy-related nausea. It is not recommended as the primary approach due to safety concerns and availability of more effective treatments.

Increase fluid intake (Option C): While increasing fluid intake is important to prevent dehydration, it is not the primary method for managing nausea and vomiting. Hydration alone does not address the underlying causes of nausea and vomiting in pregnancy.

Use metoclopramide (Option D): Metoclopramide is used for moderate to severe nausea and vomiting but is not the first choice for mild symptoms. For more severe cases, medications such as doxylamine combined with pyridoxine, or other anti-emetics, might be considered.

questions.text: A female presents to you with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, complaining of bleeding per vagina and slight abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is slightly positive, and the hCG level is 2800 IU/L. A mass is seen on the left adnexa measuring 3 x 2.5 cm. She is hemodynamically stable. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Single-dose methotrexate injection

  • The patient here is hemodynamically stable with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy with hCG levels <3000 IU/L and adnexal mass of size <4 cm; hence, the best method of treatment is medical management using single-dose methotrexate injection.

Management of Unruptured Ectopic Tubal Pregnancy

Management

Criteria/Indication

Description

Expectant Management
  • Beta hCG < 1,500 IU/L
    And falling subsequent levels
  • No significant symptoms
  • Strong likelihood of spontaneous resolution
  • Monitoring without intervention, relying on the natural resolution of the ectopic pregnancy.

Medical Management
  • Beta hCG < 3,000 IU/L
  • Adnexal mass < 4 cm
  • No fetal cardiac activity
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • Methotrexate (single dose/ multi-dose regimen) (best)
  • KCl (directly in sac)
  • Mifepristone
  • Prostaglandins

Surgical Management

(Option D)
  • Beta hCG > 5,000 IU/L
  • Size of ectopic > 4 cm
  • Presence of cardiac activity
  • Linear Salpingostomy (best)
  • Resection Anastomosis

Oral methotrexate (Option A) is not the preferred route of administration for this medication in the management of ectopic pregnancy.

Serial methotrexate with leucovorin rescue (Option C) is an option for the medical management of ectopic pregnancy, but it is typically used in cases where single-dose methotrexate is not successful or contraindicated. This approach involves administering multiple doses of methotrexate over several weeks, with leucovorin rescue given to counteract the side effects of methotrexate.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of dilation and curettage (D&C) in sequence:

 


	Serial dilation
	Curettage
	Uterine sound
	Assessment of uterine size and direction
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 4-3-1-2

 

Explanation:

The correct sequence of steps for a dilation and curettage (D&C) procedure is 4-3-1-2 (Assessment of uterine size and direction → Uterine sound → Serial dilation → Curettage)

 

Steps of Dilatation and Curettage (D&C):

 

  • Empty the patient’s bladder.
  • Perform the procedure under general anesthesia or diazepam sedation, with or without a paracervical block.
  • Place the patient in lithotomy position, clean the area with antiseptic, and drape.
  • Conduct a bimanual examination to assess uterine size and position. (4)
  • Insert a posterior vaginal speculum to visualize the cervix.
  • Grasp the anterior lip of the cervix with Allis tissue forceps or vulsellum.
  • Introduce a uterine sound to confirm uterine position and measure uterocervical length. (3)
  • Dilate the cervical canal with graduated dilators, applying traction with vulsellum. (1)
  • Curette the uterine cavity using a uterine curette in a clockwise or anticlockwise direction from fundus to internal os. (2)
  • Remove the vulsellum and speculum.
  • Preserve curetted material in 10% formol-saline, label it, and send it for histological examination.

Complications:

  • Infection
  • Hemorrhage
  • Cervical lacerations
  • Uterine perforation
  • Post-operative uterine adhesions

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about lupus nephritis in pregnancy?

choices.text: Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy
Pregnancy should be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction
High-dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy are safe
Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, and azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, and azathioprine are safe in pregnancy.

 

Explanation:

Option D is incorrect because methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and not safe during pregnancy.

These drugs should be avoided in pregnant women due to their potential to cause fetal malformations and other serious developmental effects.

 

  • Methotrexate: A folate antagonist; avoid during pregnancy due to risk of fetal malformations, including neural tube defects and craniofacial anomalies.
  • Cyclophosphamide: A cytotoxic drug; teratogenic and should only be used in pregnancy when absolutely necessary.

 

Other drugs mentioned in the list, such as ecospirin (low-dose aspirin), corticosteroids, and azathioprine, are considered relatively safer in pregnancy and are often used in managing lupus nephritis during pregnancy.

 

  • Ecospirin (low-dose aspirin): Considered safer in pregnancy; used for anticoagulant effects, especially in antiphospholipid syndrome.
  • Corticosteroids: Safe during pregnancy when appropriately managed; used for lupus flares, but higher doses may increase the risk of gestational diabetes or preterm birth.
  • Azathioprine: Safe for use in severe SLE cases during pregnancy and can be continued if needed.

 

Lupus Nephritis in Pregnancy

 

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disorder that commonly affects young women. Lupus nephritis refers to kidney involvement in SLE, which can complicate pregnancy.

 

Clinical Features:

  • Fever, weight loss, migratory joint pain, myalgias.
  • Risks: Preterm birth, preeclampsia, pregnancy loss, neonatal lupus (heart block).

 

Diagnosis:

  • Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) for screening.
  • Double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) for specific diagnosis.
  • Lupus anticoagulant, antiphospholipid antibodies, anti-Ro, and anti-La antibodies may indicate antiphospholipid syndrome.

 

Management of Lupus Nephritis in Pregnancy:

 

Preconception Planning:

Pregnancy should be planned 6 months after disease quiescence with no renal dysfunction.

 

Medications:

  • Corticosteroids: Safe for managing lupus flares during pregnancy.
  • Azathioprine: Safe for severe SLE and can be continued.
  • Hydroxychloroquine: Best for maintenance, safe in pregnancy.

 

Avoid:

Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and should not be used during pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a suitable option for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate

 

Explanation:

Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is primarily used for second-trimester terminations rather than for first-trimester MTP.

This method involves the instillation of ethacridine lactate into the amniotic sac, causing uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy. It is rarely used in modern practice due to the availability of safer and more effective methods for MTP, such as mifepristone + misoprostol.


 

Methods of Termination of Pregnancy (TOP) Across Trimesters

 

Trimester

Weeks

Medical Methods

Surgical Methods

Other Methods

First

Trimester

Up to 12 weeks

Mifepristone + Misoprostol (preferred method)
  • Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)
  • Not applicable

Second

Trimester

13-20 weeks

Misoprostol alone or with mifepristone

Dilation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Extra-amniotic Ethacridine Lactate Instillation
  • Hypertonic Saline or Urea Instillation

Third

Trimester

> 20 weeks

Rarely performed; typically involves induction of labor for therapeutic reasons.

Induction with prostaglandins (e.g., misoprostol)

Feticide procedures (e.g., intracardiac injection)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, who is pregnant for the second time, with one living child, and is at 18 weeks of gestation. She presents with a complaint of PV bleeding for the past 4 hours. On examination, her membranes are ruptured, and she is experiencing uterine contractions. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals a cervix that is shorter than 25 mm and funneling of the internal os by more than 1 cm. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cervical incompetence

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate cervical incompetence due to the features such as leaking per vaginum, uterine contractions, short cervix <25 mm & funneling of the internal os >1 cm.

Cervical Incompetence:

  • Cervical incompetence is primarily a clinical diagnosis that indicates recurrent painless dilation and spontaneous mid-trimester birth, usually of a living fetus
  • Cervical incompetence, also known as cervical insufficiency, is a condition in which the cervix begins to efface and dilate painlessly during the second trimester, leading to premature cervical dilation and often resulting in late miscarriage or preterm birth

Cervical Incompetence:

Characteristics:
  • Painless dilation of the cervix in the 2nd trimester.
  • Characterised by spontaneous, painless dilation of the cervix followed by expulsion of products of conception.

Risk factors:
  • Past history of cervical surgeries such as LEEP, conization
  • Cervical trauma (during labour or instrumental delivery)
  • Congenital abnormality

Diagnosis:

History of pregnancy loss in 2nd trimester:

  • TVUS- investigation of choice
  • Normal shape and length of the cervix- T shaped and 3-4 cm
  • Cervical length ≤2.5 cm with one 2nd trimester painless abortion, then diagnosed as cervical insufficiency

Non-pregnant women:

If Hegar no. 8 dilator can be passed through internal os without any resistance

Management:

Progesterone and cervical cerclage placement.

Incorrect Options:

Placenta previa (Option B): Placenta previa refers to the abnormal implantation of the placenta in the lower uterine segment, potentially covering the internal os of the cervix. A short cervix (25 mm) is not indicative of placenta previa. The predominant indication of placenta previa is bright red vaginal bleeding that is usually painless but is not associated with cervical shortening or funneling.

In abruptio placentae (Option C): The placenta partially or entirely separates from the uterine inner wall before birth. Abruptio placentae is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery. It typically presents with painful vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain, not necessarily associated with cervical changes.

A traumatic injury (Option D): Traumatic injury to the cervix can cause bleeding, but it is not consistent with the painless dilation and funneling seen on transvaginal ultrasound. Also, traumatic injuries are usually associated with a history of trauma or intercourse.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument/procedure?

choices.text: It is used for termination of pregnancy up to 12 weeks
Can be done on an OP basis
The capacity of the syringe is 30 ml
It created a negative pressure of 600 mmHg

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The capacity of the syringe is 30 ml

Explanation:

A manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) device is a cheap and non-invasive method well-established for surgical abortion in the first trimester of pregnancy. The manual vacuum aspirator is a 60-mL syringe in which suction of around 600 mm Hg is created manually.

  • It is used for termination of pregnancy up to 12 weeks. (Option A ruled out)
  • It can be performed on an outpatient basis under local anesthesia. (Option B ruled out)
  • It generates a negative pressure of approximately 600 mmHg manually. (Option D ruled out)

Uses of MVA Syringe

Use

Description

Pregnancy Termination
  • MVA syringes are commonly used for the termination of early pregnancies (up to 12 weeks).
  • The syringe is used to aspirate and remove the contents of the uterus.
  • It is a safe and effective method for induced abortion in appropriate settings.

Uterine Evacuation
  • MVA syringes are utilized for uterine evacuation in cases of incomplete miscarriage.
  • The syringe is used to remove retained products of conception from the uterus.

Endometrial Sampling
  • MVA syringes can be employed for endometrial sampling or biopsy procedures.
  • The syringe is used to collect a small sample of the endometrial tissue for diagnostic purposes.
  • It is commonly done to investigate abnormal uterine bleeding or to evaluate fertility issues.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of expectant management in unruptured ectopic gestation?

choices.text: Initial serum beta hCG level <200 mIU/mL

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Gestational sac size >4 cm

Explanation:

  • Expectant management (watchful waiting) involves monitoring without immediate intervention
  • A gestational sac > 4 cm is associated with an increased risk of rupture and complications, making expectant management unsafe. This size indicates a more advanced ectopic pregnancy, which typically requires active intervention, such as medical management with methotrexate or surgical treatment.

 

Indications for Expectant Management:

  • Initial beta-hCG level < 1000 IU/ml & falling
  • Gestational sac size < 4 cm
  • No fetal heartbeat on TVS
  • No evidence of bleeding or rupture
  • Asymptomatic patient

 

Initial serum beta hCG <200 mIU/mL (Option A): Appropriate for expectant management as it indicates very early or potentially non-viable pregnancy.

Asymptomatic (Option C): A favorable factor for expectant management in stable patients without concerning symptoms.

Decreasing beta hCG (Option D): Suggests possible spontaneous resolution, making expectant management appropriate.

questions.text: The usage of the given device in the picture is:

choices.text: Measure the length of the uterus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Menstrual regulation/aspiration

Explanation:

The device shown in the image is a Karman cannula, also known as the Karman curette. This device is primarily used for menstrual regulation or aspiration procedures, which involve the removal of uterine contents through suction. Key points about the device include:

  • It is commonly used for early pregnancy termination or menstrual regulation in cases of missed or incomplete abortion.
  • The procedure typically employs vacuum aspiration with the Karman cannula to safely evacuate the uterine cavity.
  • The device is specifically designed for use during the early stages of pregnancy, ensuring minimal trauma to the uterine walls.

questions.text: A woman, who is in her 8th week of pregnancy, has come seeking medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). What would be the correct dosage of misoprostol to be given through the mucosal route?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 800 mcg

Explanation:

  • Misoprostol is typically administered 1 to 2 days (24 to 48 hours) following the ingestion of mifepristone. The recommended dosage of misoprostol depends on the gestational age. For gestations up to 9 weeks (63 days), misoprostol can be administered through vaginal, buccal, or sublingual routes.
  • The recommended dose is 800 μg for vaginal, buccal, or sublingual administration and 400 μg for oral administration.

 

Option A, B, C: These options (200 mcg, 400 mcg, and 600 mcg) are incorrect because they represent lower dosages that are less likely to be effective for pregnancy termination at 8 weeks. Higher doses are needed to ensure the successful completion of the abortion process.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old primigravida at 10 weeks gestation comes to the ER with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Nausea and vomiting began one day back, and now the patient is unable to tolerate fluids. She complains of pain in the right upper quadrant, which started a few hours back. On examination, her temperature is 100.2 F, her pulse is 119 bpm, and her BP is 110/70 mm of Hg. She has swelling of her lower limbs up to the ankles bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows a gravid uterus corresponding to 10 weeks of gestation and tenderness in the right upper quadrant, with mild guarding and is diagnosed as acute appendicitis. What is the next step of management?

Laboratory Findings: Complete blood count:


	Haemoglobin: 11g/dl
	Leukocytes: 13,000 cells/μl
	Platelets: 150,000 cells/μl


Liver Function tests:


	AST: 40U/L
	ALT: 48U/L


Urinalysis:


	Protein: negative
	Pus cells: 1-2/HPF
	Bacteria: none


USG abdomen: Reveals a 9.7mm diameter, aperistaltic, non-compressible, dilated, blind-ending structure arising from the base of the caecum.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Do appendicectomy

Explanation:

The patient shows classic symptoms of appendicitis:

  • Nausea and vomiting (1 day)
  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Unable to tolerate fluids
  • Leukocytosis (13,000 cells/μl)
  • USG shows 9.7mm diameter, aperistaltic, non-compressible, dilated blind-ending structure from cecum

Acute appendicitis requires immediate surgery regardless of gestational age to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

 

Management Protocol for appendectomy in pregnancy:

  • Immediate appendicectomy indicated
  • Pre-operative care includes:
    • GI intubation
    • Parenteral replacement of IV fluids and electrolytes
    • Administration of Antibiotics
  • Antibiotics and IV fluids until surgery
  • Analgesics after diagnosis
  • Poor prognosis in pregnancy due to increased risk of abortion, sepsis, preterm labor
  • Can be performed under general/spinal anesthesia with laparoscopy or open method

 

Wait till 2nd trimester (Option B): Acute appendicitis is a surgical emergency; delaying treatment will increase the chances of complications.

Conservative management (Option C): Conservative management is not recommended with clear appendicitis signs.

Reassurance (Option D): Reassurance alone is inappropriate for suspected acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman at 13 weeks of gestation informs you about accidental exposure to radiation from a chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation. What should be the next advise to her
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Continue pregnancy

Explanation:

  • In most cases of accidental radiation exposure during early pregnancy, the risk of harm to the developing fetus is low. The radiation dose from a typical chest X-ray is relatively minimal, around 0.1 milliSievert, which is considered acceptable during pregnancy.
  • Single exposures to such low doses generally do not result in significant adverse effects on the fetus. Therefore, the appropriate course of action is to continue the pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Termination of pregnancy (Option B) is not recommended in this situation because the risk of harm to the fetus is generally considered to be low.

  • Termination of a wanted pregnancy is a significant decision and is usually reserved for situations where there is a clear and substantial risk to the fetus.

Pre-invasive diagnostic tests (Option C), such as chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis, are invasive procedures that are typically performed to assess the risk of chromosomal abnormalities in the fetus.

  • In this scenario, accidental exposure to radiation does not warrant the need for these diagnostic tests unless there are additional indications.

Chromosome screening (Option D), such as non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT), is a non-invasive screening test that analyzes cell-free fetal DNA in the maternal blood to assess the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities, such as Down syndrome.

  • In this scenario, accidental exposure to radiation does not require immediate chromosome screening unless there are other specific indications.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman in her first trimester is diagnosed with asymptomatic bacteriuria due to E. coli. What is the most common complication associated with this condition if left untreated?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pyelonephritis

Explanation:

In a 29-year-old woman in her first trimester with asymptomatic bacteriuria caused by E. coli, the most common complication if left untreated is Pyelonephritis (Pyelitis).

  • It is an infection of the upper urinary tract involving the kidneys,
  • It is mostly a complication of the lower urinary tract involving infections.
    • Infections of postoperative and puerperal cystitis often spread to the kidneys to cause pyelonephritis.
  • In pregnancy, the infective organism is usually E. coli. (Option C)
  • Ascending pyelonephritis: Complication of advanced carcinoma of the cervix and vagina.
  • Recurrent attacks: Occur in patients who have had ureterocolic transplantation
  • Clinical features
    • Pain and tenderness in the loin
      • Acute pyelonephritis: Affected kidney region is exquisitely tender
      • Chronic pyelonephritis: Tenderness and rigidity along the course of the ureter
    • High temperature
    • Frequent rigors, headache, vomiting, and furring of the tongue.
    • Increased frequency of micturition (cystitis)
  • Lab investigations:
    • Urine: Turbid, contains pus cells and bacteria
    • Toxemia (acute pyelonephritis)
      • Raised blood urea and casts present
  • Treatement
    • Keep the patient in bed, lying on the unaffected side (prevent pressure upon the tender renal angle).
    • Copious fluid administration
    • Systemic antibiotics, followed by oral fluid, for 10-14 days
    • Referral to urologist, if no response.

Incorrect Options:

Chorioamnionitis (Option A) is an infection of the fetal membranes, usually linked to prolonged rupture of membranes or invasive procedures. It is not directly associated with asymptomatic bacteriuria, making it an unlikely complication in this case.

Preterm labor (Option B) may result from untreated UTIs like pyelonephritis but is a secondary complication. The main concern with asymptomatic bacteriuria is its progression to pyelonephritis.

Low birth weight (Option D) can result from maternal infections like pyelonephritis but is not a direct or early complication of asymptomatic bacteriuria. It may occur later due to chronic infection affecting fetal growth.
